docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of hourly workers took extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with the fear that if they did not go to work , they probably would not be paid.

headline.seo: For Hourly Workers After the Storm, No Work, No Pay
headline.main: For Some After the Storm, No Work Means No Pay
headline.print_headline: For Some After the Storm, No Work Means No Pay

docs.abstract: Thousands of hourly workers in New York metropolitan area take extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with fear that if they do not go to work, they probably will not be paid; many have little choice, unsure how they will pay for storm-related damages and repairs; low-wage workers have fared worse in the recovery than those at the top of the income scale.
docs.snippet: Thousands of hourly workers took extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with the fear that if they did not go to work , they probably would not be paid.

byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and ANDREW MARTIN

docs.lead_paragraph: A new dialogue is emerging around the idea of resilience: how to help vulnerable people, organizations and systems persist, perhaps even thrive, amid unforeseeable disruptions.
docs.snippet: A new dialogue is emerging around the idea of resilience: how to help vulnerable people, organizations and systems persist, perhaps even thrive, amid unforeseeable disruptions.

docs.lead_paragraph: The anticlotting drug Pradaxa, on the market only two years, is growing in popularity for its ease of use, but it has been associated with hemorrhaging, and it has no antidote to reverse its blood-thinning effects.

headline.main: A Promising Drug With a Flaw
headline.print_headline: A Promising Drug With a Flaw

docs.abstract: Anticlotting drug Pradaxa is growing in popularity for its ease of use, but has been associated with hemorrhaging and has no antidote to reverse its blood-thinning effects; Pradaxa has been linked to more than 500 bleeding deaths in its two years on the market; drug has become a blockbuster for its maker Boehringer Ingelheim, bringing in more than $1 billion in sales.
docs.snippet: The anticlotting drug Pradaxa, on the market only two years, is growing in popularity for its ease of use, but it has been associated with hemorrhaging, and it has no antidote to reverse its blood-thinning effects.

docs.lead_paragraph: What federal tax rate would you pay if Mitt Romney were elected president? And what would it be under President Obama’s proposal? How would that stack up against the richest Americans?

headline.main: Comparing the Tax Bite With Obama and Romney
headline.print_headline: Comparing The Tax Bite With Obama And Romney

docs.abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column on different federal tax rates that would be paid if Mitt Romney is elected president, or if Pres Obama wins reelection, assuming Congress goes along with the candidates' proposals.
docs.snippet: What federal tax rate would you pay if Mitt Romney were elected president? And what would it be under President Obama’s proposal? How would that stack up against the richest Americans?

headline.main: Assessing the Impact of Health Care Reform on New Businesses In Massachusetts

docs.abstract: You might think that the increased availability of health insurance would make it easier for entrepreneurs to quit jobs and start businesses — but it’s not easy to prove.
docs.snippet: You might think that the increased availability of health insurance would make it easier for entrepreneurs to quit jobs and start businesses — but it’s not easy to prove.

docs.lead_paragraph: The presidential election in this swing state hangs in an area where the electorate is prone to shifting between red and blue.

headline.main: In Wisconsin, Real Battleground Is Rural
headline.print_headline: In Wisconsin, Real Battleground Is Rural

docs.abstract: Presidential election in swing state of Wisconsin hangs in rural northern tier where the electorate is prone to shifting between red and blue; candidates view it as telltale of whether state's political upheaval since 2010 has undermined Pres Obama's bulwark of support.
docs.snippet: The presidential election in this swing state hangs in an area where the electorate is prone to shifting between red and blue.

docs.lead_paragraph: Policy makers are being urged to address long-term unemployment before those looking for work decide to give up trying for good.

headline.main: Little Federal Help for the Long-Term Unemployed

docs.abstract: Policy makers are being urged to address long-term unemployment in United States before those looking for work become hopeless and decide to give up trying for good; nearly five million Americans out of work for six months or more are left to wonder what help, if any, is coming, as Federal Reserve, International Monetary Fund and bipartisan policy experts implore Washington to act.
docs.snippet: Policy makers are being urged to address long-term unemployment before those looking for work decide to give up trying for good.

byline.contributor: Annie Lowrey reported from Washington and Catherine Rampell from New York.
byline.original: By ANNIE LOWREY and CATHERINE RAMPELL

docs.lead_paragraph: Confidence grew in October to its highest level in nearly five years, encouraged by recent declines in the jobless rate.

headline.seo: Consumer Confidence and Spending Rise, Reports Show
headline.main: Consumer Confidence and Spending Are Rising, Economic Reports Show
headline.print_headline: Consumer Confidence and Spending Are Rising, Economic Reports Show

docs.abstract: Conference Board reports that American consumers are growing more confident and spending more, with consumer confidence surging to its highest level in nearly five years; consumer confidence index rose to 72.2 in October, its highest reading since February 2008; Labor Dept reports weekly unemployment applications fell 9,000 to 363,000 in previous week.
docs.snippet: Confidence grew in October to its highest level in nearly five years, encouraged by recent declines in the jobless rate.
